comments_since_last_sample.body:
Hello and welcome to r/LifeProTips!

Please help us decide if this post is a good fit for the subreddit by up or downvoting this comment. 

If you think that this is great advice to improve your life, please upvote. If you think this doesn't help you in any way, please downvote. If you don't care, leave it for the others to decide.

I was dating someone that had pretty traditional Asian parents. I would say she's a good kid that's successful in almost every metric aside from emotional maturity.

I think she would make a great kid but I can tell you that she makes a horrible partner because she's emotionally incommunicative.
I guess this is more a relationship tip than a parenting tip, but neither are allowed here.

Love this tip. You're not saying "*would* you like your child to be like them when they grow up?" as that's a different question and not at all what you're saying. You're just asking to imagine if they were like them, how would you feel?

You can have issues with someone and still be in love with them, and you can have zero issues with someone and not be in love with them, and I think this question abstracts it in a way where you can figure out how you feel without having to get to the nitty gritty. Beautiful question. 

Ofcourse, any children you might have (or might not have) aren't going to grow up exactly like either of you, and you wouldn't actually want a weird mini-me running around, lol. But if they did, you can imagine how you'd feel. Happy? Disappointed? That's feeling is saying something about your partner too then.

I'm not sure if I want to raise a child growing up to be exactly like me. In fact, I'm pretty sure I don't. The other factor is you may love the concept of the kid coming out exactly like them and yet other genes kick in and the kid is hard for both of you to deal with. So while this idea can help screen out some characters, I'm not so sure if this as a guiding principle/ life pro tip.

Not a bad tip. Definitely a good thought experiment.

But I can't *not* remind everyone: Don't expect your children to actually *be* small versions of you/your partner. Those kinds of expectations lead to very bad parenting.

I'd also add that during covid I'm watching people I know in previously healthy relationships - now falling apart. I kind of want to tell them to let covid pass before making big decisions, that being forced into close proximity like this for years will have issues... but I learned long ago, not to get involved in that kind of fight.

Also applies to yourself.
If you wanna know how much you love yourself imagine your children growing up to be exactly like you.
I mean honestly if I'm struggling to figure out if I even like them, the answer for me is probably "not enough"
